    "coverageText": "Overview  
This editorial review focuses on sharpening your thesis and evaluation criteria, tightening grammar and tone, and structuring your book review into the classic intro–summary–analysis–conclusion format. We’ll ensure you meet MLA requirements for book titles and quotes, keep spoilers to the midpoint, and maintain an analytical yet accessible style for classmates and your teacher.

Overall Feedback  
• Thesis clarity: Your review needs a clear evaluative statement up front—what aspect of The Giver you’re judging (symbolism, pacing, ending, etc.) and why those criteria matter.  
• Tone and voice: Shift from casual phrasing (“I liked…”) toward analytical observations supported by evidence. Keep your personal response but frame it in an academic register.  
• Line-by-line polish: Several sentences need subject-verb fixes, punctuation around introductory clauses, and smoother transitions.  
• Structure: Organize into four distinct sections—intro with thesis, concise summary (no major spoilers), analysis paragraphs on symbolism, pacing, ending, and a closing recommendation that ties back to your thesis.

Spelling Edits  
• “its” in “its not.”  
  – Corrected to “it’s” (contraction of “it is”).  
  – Issue: punctuation/grammar—apostrophe needed.

Grammar Edits  
• Original: In The Giver by Lois Lowry, the community seems perfect but actually its not.  
  – Revision: In The Giver by Lois Lowry, the community seems perfect, but it’s not.  
  – Issue: missing comma before “but”; needs “it’s” (contraction) for “it is.”  
• Original: I liked the way the author use color as a symbol of freedom and choice.  
  – Revision: I liked the way the author uses color as a symbol of freedom and choice.  
  – Issue: subject–verb agreement (“author uses”).  
• Original: When Jonas first sees the apple “change,” it foreshadows him seeing the world differently.  
  – Revision: When Jonas first sees the apple “change,” it foreshadows his altered view of the world.  
  – Issue: pronoun (“him” → “his”) and clarity.  
• Original: The pacing in the middle got slow for me and I think the ending was confusing but good.  
  – Revision: The pacing in the middle slowed down, and although the ending was initially confusing, it ultimately proved effective.  
  – Issue: tense consistency, comma splice, and tone—replace “got slow for me” with a more formal structure.  
• Original: Overall I would recommend this book because it makes you think about choices and memory and what is price of safety.  
  – Revision: Overall, I would recommend this book because it prompts readers to consider the connections between choice, memory, and the price of safety.  
  – Issue: missing comma after “Overall,” run-on ideas, awkward word order (“what the price of safety is”).

Structural Suggestions  
• Intro paragraph:  
  – Add a strong thesis sentence that names your evaluation criteria (symbolism, pacing, ending clarity) and your overall judgment.  
  – Explain briefly why these criteria matter to you as a reader.  
• Summary section:  
  – Insert a concise, spoiler-light summary of the plot up to mid-point. One paragraph only.  
  – Avoid revealing events beyond the community’s revelations or Jonas’s first training experiences.  
• Analysis section:  
  – Organize three short paragraphs, each with a clear topic sentence:  
    1. Symbolism of color (quote the apple scene; MLA-cite page).  
    2. Pacing in the middle chapters (give an example of a quieter scene).  
    3. Ending’s clarity (describe what felt confusing and why it still worked).  
  – This improves flow by grouping related ideas.  
• Conclusion paragraph:  
  – Restate your refined thesis and tie it back to why classmates should read it.  
  – Offer a final evaluative statement on the book’s impact.

Opportunities for Improvement  
• Transitions: Use linking words (Furthermore, However, In addition) to guide the reader between ideas.  
• Evidence and examples: Integrate at least one direct quote from the text, followed by brief analysis—this strengthens your argument.  
• Balance summary and analysis: Keep the summary short so you have space to analyze key points in depth.  
• Tone: Swap informal phrases (“got slow for me,” “but good”) for more precise academic language (“slowed,” “effective”).

Formatting Guidance  
• MLA book title formatting: Italicize The Giver.  
• Quote formatting: Use quotation marks around any text from the novel, and include an in-text citation—e.g., (Lowry 45).  
• Document style: Double-space your review in 12pt Times New Roman with 1" margins.  
• Paragraphing: Indent the first line of each paragraph one half-inch.  
• Heading (optional): At top left, include your name, teacher’s name, course, and date, double-spaced, then center the title.

Would you like me to generate a fully revised version of your review that incorporates these suggestions? Or is there another area where you’d like more guidance?",

OK",
    "coverage": "ok"

    "coverageText": "Overview  
Based on your goals—to improve clarity, ensure consistent tense and style, strengthen the argument’s coherence, and apply Chicago footnote formatting—this feedback focuses on line-level grammar and style edits, concrete structural suggestions, and guidance on placing and formatting footnotes according to the Notes-Bibliography style.

Overall Feedback  
• Your thesis is clear: the New Deal reshaped the citizen–government relationship despite not ending the Depression.  
• Sentence-level phrasing can be tightened for precision (e.g., “both too much and not enough” → “excessive and insufficient”).  
• Maintain consistent past tense when describing historical events.  
• Strengthen coherence by linking your examples directly back to the thesis in each sentence.  
• Ensure footnote markers follow Chicago conventions (placed after punctuation) and include page numbers in the actual footnotes.

Spelling Edits  
• No misspellings found: all words in the excerpt are correctly spelled. (Spelling)

Grammar Edits  
• Subject-verb agreement: In “policies had limits that shows the contradictions,” change shows → show to match plural subject “policies.”  
  – Issue: subject-verb agreement; rationale: “policies” is plural, so the verb must also be plural.  
• Concision and clarity: “were criticized as being both too much and not enough” → “were criticized as both excessive and insufficient.”  
  – Issue: style/clarity; rationale: “excessive and insufficient” is more precise and formal.

Structural Suggestions  
• Combine the first two sentences for a stronger topic sentence:  
  – Move “However” into the same sentence: “Although the New Deal did not end the Great Depression, it redefined the relationship between citizens and the federal government.”  
  – Improvement: creates a single, punchy introduction that clearly states your argument.  
• Tie each example back to your thesis explicitly:  
  – After the CCC example, add a brief clause: “…reinforced certain gender norms, illustrating how relief programs simultaneously advanced and constrained social roles.”  
  – Improvement: reinforces coherence by linking evidence to the central claim.  
• Revise the concluding sentence to preview your paper’s next point or to encapsulate your argument’s implication:  
  – For instance, “Although these reforms were unprecedented in scope, their limitations reveal inherent contradictions that shaped subsequent New Deal policies.”  
  – Improvement: provides a clear transition and emphasizes the argument’s broader significance.

Opportunities for Improvement  
• Expand on “reinforced certain gender norms” by briefly noting which norms or expectations were highlighted.  
• Specify which domestic-worker exclusions most affected Black women (e.g., Social Security exclusion) to deepen your evidence.  
• Add transitional phrases (e.g., “Moreover,” “Consequently”) between sentences to guide the reader through your logic.  
• Consider integrating a brief quotation from a primary source, formatted as a Chicago footnote, to strengthen authoritative support.

Formatting Guidance  
• Footnote placement: In Chicago style, place the footnote marker after the sentence’s closing punctuation (e.g., period or comma).  
• Footnote content: Replace [1], [2] placeholders with full citations including author, title, page number.  
• Page numbers: Ensure each footnote lists the specific page(s) you’re citing.  
• Quotation format: If you introduce a direct quote under 100 words, enclose it in quotation marks and cite via footnote. For longer quotations, use block-quote formatting (indented, no quotation marks).  
• Paragraphing: Keep single-idea paragraphs concise (3–5 sentences) to enhance readability.  

Would you like me to generate a revised version of your excerpt that incorporates all these suggestions? Do you need further assistance or additional guidance on any point?",

text: Title: How I Stopped Procrastinating By Doing Less
Intro: I used to think I need more apps to fix my procrastination. Turns out, I needed less—less options, less tabs, less guilt.
## Tip 1: Make a Not-To-Do List
This is not negative! It focuses your attention on what you should ignore. For example, checking Twitter every 10 minutes is a bad loop I had.
## Tip 2: Set "good enough" deadlines
Perfectionism is a trap. If you schedule shorter blocks and accept B+ work at first, you will move faster.
## Conclusion
Doing less is surprisingly brave. You will feel weird at first, but then free.",

OK",

    "coverageText": "Overview  
Based on your goals of tightening structure, improving headings, fixing grammar, and enhancing readability for the web, this edit focuses on consistent past tense in anecdotes, clearer headings (H2 for main sections, H3 for subpoints), scannable bullets, and trimming repetition while keeping your friendly, practical tone.

Overall Feedback  
Your draft has strong takeaways and a friendly voice that suits productivity readers. To strengthen it, maintain past-tense consistency in your anecdote, clarify your “why” early on, and use subheadings and bullets to break up dense text. A brief intro that previews your three core tips (Not-To-Do List, “Good Enough” deadlines, and letting go) will help readers scan quickly and stay engaged.

Spelling Edits  
• No spelling errors detected. (Spelling)

Grammar Edits  
• “I used to think I need more apps to fix my procrastination.”  
  – Revision: “I used to think I needed more apps to fix my procrastination.”  
  – Reason: past-tense consistency in the anecdote. (Tense consistency)  
• “…less options, less tabs, less guilt.”  
  – Revision: “…fewer options, fewer tabs, and less guilt.”  
  – Reason: use “fewer” for countable items (“options,” “tabs”) and add “and” for parallel structure. (Grammar, style)  
• “This is not negative! It focuses your attention on what you should ignore.”  
  – Revision: “This isn’t negative—it helps you focus on what to ignore.”  
  – Reason: smoother flow by using a dash and a contraction to match your friendly tone. (Style, clarity)  
• “For example, checking Twitter every 10 minutes is a bad loop I had.”  
  – Revision: “For example, I used to check Twitter every 10 minutes, which created a distracting loop.”  
  – Reason: clarifies subject and improves readability. (Clarity, grammar)  
• “Perfectionism is a trap. If you schedule shorter blocks and accept B+ work at first, you will move faster.”  
  – Revision: “Perfectionism is a trap. By scheduling shorter work blocks and accepting B+ quality at first, you’ll move faster.”  
  – Reason: parallel phrasing and contraction for a more conversational tone. (Style, clarity)

Structural Suggestions  
• Reorder intro to preview all tips: start with a one-sentence hook (“I thought more apps would help…”) then list your three solutions in brief. This orients readers up front. (Coherence, flow)  
• Combine the anecdote about Twitter with Tip 1 paragraph to avoid repetition. For example, fold “I used to check Twitter…” directly under the Not-To-Do List heading. (Trimming repetition, coherence)  
• Expand Conclusion into a call-to-action: after “you will feel free,” add “Try these steps this week and share your experience in the comments.” This invites engagement. (Reader engagement, flow)  

Opportunities for Improvement  
• Add a brief personal example under Tip 2 (e.g., a mini case study of a task you completed faster). This strengthens credibility. (Evidence)  
• Include a transitional sentence between tips (e.g., “Once you’ve set boundaries with a Not-To-Do List, the next step…”). This improves readability. (Transitions)  
• Consider a short bulleted list of “common not-to-do items” (social media, email refresh) to make Tip 1 more actionable. (Clarity, practicality)

Formatting Guidance  
• Use H2 for main sections (Intro, Tip 1, Tip 2, Conclusion) and H3 or bold for subheadings within tips. This aligns with web style.  
• Break paragraphs into 2–3 sentences max. Short blocks aid scanning.  
• Convert examples or mini-steps into scannable bullet lists under each tip.  
• Keep your links intact but format them as clickable anchor text (e.g., [Your App Review](https://example.com)).  
• Add a Table of Contents at the top with jump-links to each H2 to help long-form readers.

Would you like me to generate a fully rewritten version of your blog post draft incorporating these suggestions? Or is there another area you’d like more help with?",

    "coverageText": "Overview  
This feedback focuses on improving tense consistency, clarity, and conciseness while preserving your data. We’ll restructure the abstract into Background, Methods, Results, and Conclusion. Edits will remove first-person phrasing, define acronyms, and ensure a formal, objective tone suitable for science fair judges reviewing a scientific abstract under a 250-word limit.

Overall Feedback  
• Tone and voice: Shift from first-person to passive or neutral constructions (e.g., “was designed” instead of “we designed”).  
• Tense consistency: Use past tense throughout to report completed work.  
• Clarity and conciseness: Eliminate filler phrases (“which is why”), define acronyms (DIY → do-it-yourself), and specify units on first use (micrometer (µm)).  
• Structure: Clearly separate Background, Methods, Results, and Conclusion to guide judges through your study.

Spelling Edits  
• No spelling errors detected. (Spelling check) All technical terms and common words are spelled correctly.

Grammar Edits  
• “Plastic waste in waterways is increasing, which is why we designed a low-cost microplastic filter…”  
  – Suggested: “Plastic waste in waterways is increasing. A low-cost microplastic filter was designed…”  
  – Issue: grammar/tense consistency and avoidance of first-person. Splitting the sentence improves focus.  
• “We test filtration rates and particle counts with a DIY microscope rig.”  
  – Suggested: “Filtration rates and particle counts were measured using a do-it-yourself (DIY) microscope rig.”  
  – Issue: tense consistency (past tense), first-person removal, acronym definition.  
• “Results shows a 42% mean reduction…”  
  – Suggested: “Results show a 42% mean reduction…”  
  – Issue: subject-verb agreement (plural “Results” needs “show”), tense consistency.  
• “18% reduction in 50–100 μm.”  
  – Suggested: “an 18% reduction in particles sized 50–100 micrometers (µm).”  
  – Issue: clarity (state what is reduced), unit definition, avoid dangling phrase.

Structural Suggestions  
• Background: Start with “Plastic waste in waterways is increasing.” This orients the reader immediately.  
• Methods: Combine design and testing description: “A low-cost microplastic filter using natural fibers was designed and tested on local creek samples. Filtration rates and particle counts were measured using a do-it-yourself (DIY) microscope rig.”  
  – Improves flow by grouping all procedural information.  
• Results: Present percentage reductions in one sentence: “Results show a 42% mean reduction in particles larger than 100 micrometers (µm) after 30 minutes and an 18% reduction in particles sized 50–100 µm.”  
  – Consolidates findings for readability.  
• Conclusion: End with limitations and future potential: “Limitations include inconsistent flow and clogging; however, the design can be scaled for classroom use.”  
  – Clearly signals the end of the abstract and its implications.

Opportunities for Improvement  
• Add context on sample size or number of trials to strengthen credibility.  
• Indicate measurement uncertainty or standard deviation if available.  
• Include a brief statement on the filter’s material properties or cost to highlight “low-cost.”  
• Use transition words (e.g., “however,” “therefore”) to link sentences smoothly.  

Formatting Guidance  
• Keep the entire abstract under 250 words; aim for a single paragraph divided logically by clauses or semicolons.  
• Avoid headers in the submitted abstract unless required; use clear signposting phrases (Background, Methods, etc.).  
• Define all acronyms on first use (e.g., do-it-yourself (DIY), micrometer (µm)).  
• Use SI units and Greek letters correctly (µm for micrometers).  
• Ensure consistent punctuation around percentages and units (e.g., “42 %,” “100 µm”).

Would you like me to generate a rewritten version of your abstract incorporating these suggestions? Do you need any additional guidance or further revisions?",

    "coverageText": "Overview  
Based on your goals—polishing tone and clarity, ensuring coherence, and trimming filler while keeping your authentic voice—this feedback will sharpen your scholarship essay’s narrative flow and tighten language for a selection committee. I focus on making each sentence purposeful, maintaining a hopeful, sincere tone, and respecting your 500-word limit in plain-text paragraphs of 4–6 sentences.

Overall Feedback  
• Your introduction shows resilience and responsibility, which is exactly what scholarship committees want to see.  
• Some sentences can be tightened or reordered to improve flow and reduce filler.  
• Strengthen the connection between your personal story and how the scholarship will directly impact your academic progress.  
• Maintain your authentic voice—brief, sincere, and forward-looking—while ensuring each detail contributes to your main message.

Spelling Edits  
• No spelling errors detected. (Spelling – your word choices are all correct.)

Grammar Edits  
• “busy is how I stayed steady” → Consider “being busy helped me stay steady” (Parallel structure – “being busy” pairs two gerunds for clarity).  
• “Once, I missed a shift to take him to an appointment and got written up,” → Add a comma: “Once, I missed a shift to take him to an appointment, and I got written up,” (Comma usage – separate two independent clauses).  
• “I’m not perfect and I still overcommit, but I’ve learned to ask for help and to say no.” → Add comma before “and”: “I’m not perfect, and I still overcommit, but I’ve learned to ask for help and say no.” (Comma usage – clarity in compound sentence; parallel verbs “ask” and “say”).  
• “choose time for classes” → Consider “free up time for my classes” (Verb choice – “free up” more clearly conveys making space in your schedule).

Structural Suggestions  
• Lead with context: Move “when things were uncertain at home” earlier. For example, “When things were uncertain at home, being busy helped me stay steady.” This sets the scene before introducing outside opinions.  
• Combine related ideas: Merge the first two sentences into one concise opener. It tightens pacing and removes filler.  
• End with impact: After explaining how the scholarship helps you, briefly state a goal (e.g., “This support will allow me to focus on coursework and ultimately pursue [your long-term goal]”). It reinforces purpose and leaves a lasting impression.  
• Ensure each sentence answers “Why does this matter to the committee?” or “How does this advance my story?”

Opportunities for Improvement  
• Add a concrete example of balancing tasks (e.g., hours per week, specific subject you excelled in despite time constraints) to illustrate your work ethic.  
• Include a short reflection on what you’ve learned about leadership or time management. That insight shows personal growth.  
• Use transitional words (“As a result,” “Because of this,”) sparingly to guide readers through your narrative without sounding formal.  
• Ensure your closing paragraph ties back to the opening and underscores your hopefulness and sincerity.

Formatting Guidance  
• Keep this as a single paragraph of 4–6 sentences, since scholarship essays often favor concise, impactful blocks.  
• Plain text only: no headings or bullet lists in the final submission.  
• Watch your total word count—aim for ~480–490 words to leave room for last-minute edits.  
• Standard font (e.g., Times New Roman or Arial 11–12 pt), 1-inch margins, double-spaced (if the committee has formatting guidelines).

Would you like me to produce a revised version of your paragraph incorporating these changes? And do you need further assistance, additional edits, or more guidance?",

    "coverageText": "Overview  
Based on your goals—to standardize the narrative in American English, address code-switching, and fix grammar/tense—this edit focuses on keeping your cultural references while converting Spanish phrases into clear, idiomatic English. We’ll preserve your personal voice and conversational tone for your high-school teacher audience.

Overall Feedback  
Your paragraph clearly conveys the challenge and growth in switching between Spanish and English. You have a strong narrative voice and honest reflections, but a few expressions still reflect Spanish structure and there are minor grammar choices that can interrupt flow. Cleaning up these moments will make your experience even more relatable and easy to follow.

Spelling Edits  
- No spelling errors found. Your words are all correctly spelled. (Issue: spelling – no action needed.)

Grammar Edits  
- “Mi familia and I moved to the U.S. when I was 10” → “My family and I moved to the U.S. when I was ten.”  
  • Issue: style/consistency. Rationale: Switching “Mi familia” to “My family” keeps it in standard American English. Spelling out “ten” aligns with conventional age notation in narratives.  
- “at la escuela office” → “at the school office.”  
  • Issue: dialect and clarity. Rationale: Translating “la escuela” to “the school” uses standard terms and removes code-switching mid-sentence.  
- “Sometimes I say things like ‘I have 15 years’ because that’s how we say it in Spanish,” → “Sometimes I say things like ‘I’m 15 years old’ because in Spanish we literally say ‘I have 15 years,’”  
  • Issue: grammar and clarity. Rationale: “I’m 15 years old” is the correct English equivalent. Placing the Spanish phrase in quotation clarifies its origin.  
- “It be confusing switching back and forth,” → “It can be confusing to switch back and forth,”  
  • Issue: tense/formality. Rationale: “It can be confusing” uses a standard modal construction instead of nonstandard “be.”  
- “but I’m learning to slow down and think in English first when needed, and also not be ashamed of speaking both.” → “but I’m learning to slow down, think in English first when I need to, and not be ashamed of speaking both languages.”  
  • Issue: parallel structure. Rationale: Adding “languages” clarifies “both,” and ensuring each verb phrase follows the same pattern improves readability.

Structural Suggestions  
- Split the first sentence for clarity. Consider:  
  1) “When I was ten, my family and I moved to the U.S.”  
  2) “At the school office, I used to translate for my parents.”  
  • Improves flow by separating background (move) from your translating role.  
- Move the explanation of “I have 15 years” immediately after mentioning code-switching:  
  • This groups all examples of language mixing into one spot, making your narrative progression smoother.  
- Consider adding a brief concluding sentence on how these experiences shape you today, e.g.: “That practice not only helped my parents but also made me more confident in both languages.”  
  • Provides a stronger wrap-up and reinforces your growth.

Opportunities for Improvement  
- Add specific feelings or reactions (e.g., “I felt embarrassed when people laughed” or “I laughed along”) to deepen emotional engagement.  
- Include a transition word (however, although, even though) before “but I’m learning…” to strengthen connection between confusion and personal growth.  
- If space allows, give one concrete example of translating at school to illustrate your role and its impact.

Formatting Guidance  
- Keep all Spanish terms (if you choose to retain any) in italics: e.g., *la escuela*.  
- Use standard paragraphing without extra line breaks for a personal-narrative paragraph.  
- Use straight quotation marks around spoken phrases: “I’m 15 years old.”  
- Maintain one-inch margins and a readable font (e.g., Times New Roman, 12 pt) for submission to a teacher.

Would you like me to generate a revised version of your paragraph incorporating these suggestions? Would you also like any further changes or guidance?",

This edit focuses on tightening your executive summary for clarity and impact. I’ve guided you to:  
- Clarify the **value proposition** and **problem statement** up front  
- Use a consistent, confident tone without hype  
- Fix small grammar and punctuation issues  
- Restructure into clear sections (Value Proposition, Problem, Pilot Results, Growth Plan, Risks & Mitigation)  
- Format with H2/H3 headings, bullets, and bold key metrics  

Overall Feedback  
Your summary clearly presents the core idea and impressive pilot metrics. To sharpen its impact for small business owners, let’s:  
- Lead with a concise **value proposition**  
- State the **problem** in one punchy sentence  
- Combine pilot results into a tight bullet list for scannability  
- Sequence content in a logical flow (What, Why, How, Results, Next Steps)  
- Keep tone confident and direct, removing words that dilute authority (for example, “simple” or “which we plan to”)  

Spelling Edits  
- “ads that works” → “ads that work”  
  Rationale (grammar): Corrects subject–verb agreement  

Grammar Edits  
- Original: “small shops don’t have time or money to run ads that works.”  
  Correction: “small shops don’t have time or money to run ads that work.”  
  Issue (grammar): Subject–verb agreement  

- Original: “With our pilot of 18 stores, average foot traffic increased 12% in 6 weeks, with 9 stores renewing for the next quarter.”  
  Correction: “In our pilot of 18 stores, average foot traffic increased by 12% over six weeks; nine stores have already renewed for the next quarter.”  
  Issue (grammar/clarity): Avoid comma splice; spell out “six”—improves readability  

- Original: “break-even at 320 paying locations”  
  Correction: “achieve break-even at 320 paying locations”  
  Issue (clarity): Adds verb to complete the thought  

- Original: “Risks include churn and notification fatigue which we plan to mitigate with controls.”  
  Correction: “Risks include churn and notification fatigue, which we plan to mitigate through specific controls.”  
  Issue (grammar/clarity): Adds missing comma and clarifies “controls”  

Structural Suggestions  
- Reorder into clear subsections:  
  H2 Value Proposition → H2 Problem → H2 Pilot Results → H2 Growth Plan → H2 Risks & Mitigation  
  This creates a logical narrative arc from what you do to how you’ll scale.  
- Under “Pilot Results,” use bullets for each key metric (e.g., “+12% foot traffic,” “50% renewal rate”) so metrics stand out.  
- Combine redundant phrases (“using geo-targeted notifications and simple onboarding”) into one succinct phrase under Value Proposition.  
- Expand “controls” slightly (for example, “frequency caps” or “opt-out options”) to show concrete planning.  

Opportunities for Improvement  
- Add a brief example or testimonial from one pilot store to humanize the data.  
- Quantify cost savings or ROI if available (e.g., “cost per new customer decreased by 20%”).  
- Insert a transition sentence before Risks to signal that you’re moving from results to caution points (e.g., “While results are promising, we recognize key risks…”).  

Formatting Guidance  
- Use H2 headings (e.g., “## Pilot Results”) and H3 subheads for bullet groups.  
- Bold critical figures and terms (for example, **12%**, **Q3**, **break-even**).  
- Present metrics in bullet lists for quick scanning by busy owners.  
- Maintain consistent spacing (one blank line between sections).  
- If you include footnotes or references, use a simple superscript and list style at the end.  

Would you like me to produce a fully rewritten version of this executive summary incorporating these changes? Or do you need any additional tweaks or guidance?",

text: - Hook: “Imagine if your phone is the boss of you.”
- Problem: Screen time going up; attention going down.
- Evidence: grades slipping, sleep shorter, I felt it last semester.
- Counter: Phones are tools—yes, but tools shape us.
- Solution: 3 steps: grayscale, no-phone mornings, buddy check-ins.
- Close: “You deserve your attention back.” Ask audience to try it for 7 days.",
    "validityText": "The input is a user-provided piece of writing (a persuasive speech outline) accompanied by meta-instructions (goals, type_of_writing, target audience, feedback focus, formatting, tone preferences, constraints) that the assistant should use when editing. This exactly matches the specification: it is natural-language writing to be edited, includes meta-instructions, and is presented as plain text. Therefore, it complies with the input specification.

OK",
    "validity": "ok",
    "coverageText": "Overview  
This feedback focuses on turning your persuasive speech outline into a smooth, 5–6-minute presentation for your classmates. We’ll refine grammar and transitions, strengthen the motivational but grounded tone, and reorganize content so each section flows logically. Finally, you’ll get clear formatting guidance for your speaking notes, including cue words and spacing.

Overall Feedback  
• You have a strong, relatable hook and a clear problem–solution structure.  
• The evidence section needs more concrete details and smoother transitions to keep your classmates engaged.  
• Addressing the counterargument is effective but could use a transition phrase and brief explanation to strengthen your point.  
• Your three-step solution is concise, but you can expand each step slightly to meet the time requirement and make it actionable.  
• Close with a powerful call to action—spell out exactly what you want your peers to do over the next seven days.

Spelling Edits  
• No spelling errors found. (Spelling check) Your outline’s key words are all spelled correctly.

Grammar Edits  
• “Screen time going up; attention going down.”  
  – Corrected: “Screen time is increasing, and attention spans are decreasing.”  
  – Issue: grammar (subject–verb agreement) and clarity. Adding verbs makes it a complete sentence and keeps the parallel structure.  
• “grades slipping, sleep shorter, I felt it last semester.”  
  – Corrected: “Grades are slipping, sleep is shorter, and I felt these effects last semester.”  
  – Issue: parallel structure and clarity. Use full verbs and consistent phrasing for each item.  
• “Phones are tools—yes, but tools shape us.”  
  – Corrected: “Phones are tools, yes, but these tools shape us.”  
  – Issue: punctuation. A comma after “tools” softens the break and improves flow.  
• “Ask audience to try it for 7 days.”  
  – Corrected: “Ask the audience to try these steps for seven days.”  
  – Issue: clarity and style. Spell out “seven” (style) and specify “these steps” so the call to action is clear.

Structural Suggestions  
• Hook → Problem/Evidence: After your hook, add a one-sentence transition like, “Here’s why that matters to all of us.” This will guide listeners into the problem.  
• Combine “Problem” and “Evidence”: Rather than separate bullets, narrate: “Over the last year, my average screen time shot up by two hours a day, my grades dipped from a B+ to a B–, and I was waking up exhausted.” This merges evidence and personal anecdote for impact.  
• Counterargument placement: Introduce it with “Now, you might be thinking…” This sets up the objection before you refute it.  
• Solution expansion: Label each step (“Step 1: Switch to grayscale,” etc.), then add a brief “why this works” sentence under each. That helps fill time and gives classmates context.  
• Close with call to action: End with a clear challenge—“Will you join me in regaining control of your attention? Let’s start today, for the next seven days.” This frames the ask as a group effort.

Opportunities for Improvement  
• Add a brief data point or statistic (e.g., average teen screen time) to strengthen your evidence.  
• Use a short personal story or visual image to make the problem relatable.  
• Include a rhetorical question or quick audience poll (“How many of you check Instagram first thing?”) for engagement.  
• Vary sentence length and tone—mix shorter, punchy lines with longer, explanatory ones to maintain interest.

Formatting Guidance  
• Headings: Label each main section in your notes—HOOK, PROBLEM, EVIDENCE, COUNTERARGUMENT, SOLUTION, CALL TO ACTION.  
• Cue words: Insert [PAUSE] after your hook, [EMPHASIZE] before a key fact, [LOOK AROUND] when engaging classmates.  
• Spacing: Leave one line blank between sections so you can turn pages without losing your place.  
• Indentation: Use bullet points for sub-ideas under each heading, and number your three steps clearly.  
• Timing notes: In the margin, jot time targets (e.g., “1 min for Hook,” “2 min for Evidence”) to stay within 5–6 minutes.

Would you like me to generate a rewritten version of your speech outline incorporating all these suggestions? Let me know if you’d like more assistance, deeper edits, or additional guidance.",

    "coverageText": "Overview  
Based on your goal of improving chronology, maintaining consistent tense, and sharpening descriptive clarity in this personal narrative, I’ve focused on aligning the events in clear chronological order, unifying past tense throughout, and suggesting ways to vary sentence structure. The feedback also preserves your reflective, hopeful tone while keeping all major events intact.

Overall Feedback  
• Chronology and tense consistency: Right now, the narrative shifts between present and past tense and jumps around in time. Converting everything to the past tense and arranging the sentences to follow the actual sequence of events will make the story flow more smoothly for your English class.  
• Descriptive clarity: A few concrete details—like how the ice looked or how physical therapy felt—will bring your reflection to life. Short, sensory phrases can deepen the reader’s connection.  
• Sentence variety: You open several sentences with “I.” Varying your sentence openings and combining some shorter sentences can improve rhythm and keep the reader engaged.  

Spelling Edits  
• No spelling errors were detected in the provided text. All words conform to standard American English spelling.

Grammar Edits  
• “I am limping down the stairs last winter when the ice was invisible, and then I fell.”  
  – Suggestion: Change to “I was limping down the stairs last winter when invisible ice sent me tumbling.”  
  – Issue: tense consistency (grammar) and clarity (style). Converting “am limping” to “was limping” keeps past tense consistent, and restructuring combines two actions for smoother flow.  
• “Later, in physical therapy, I learn patience I didn’t know I had.”  
  – Suggestion: Change “learn” to “learned.”  
  – Issue: tense consistency (grammar). Past tense “learned” matches the timeline.  
• “By spring I was jogging, then I am running.”  
  – Suggestion: Change “then I am running” to “then I was running.”  
  – Issue: tense consistency (grammar). Unifying past tense preserves the retrospective narrative.  
• “The day I broke my ankle is the day I decided to join track, which doesn’t make sense until I explain.”  
  – Suggestion: Change “doesn’t” to “didn’t,” or consider rephrasing to “may not make sense yet.”  
  – Issue: tense consistency (grammar) and tone (clarity). “Didn’t” matches past tense; “yet” softens the transition.  

Structural Suggestions  
• Open with the fall, then explain the decision:  
  – Move “The day I broke my ankle…” after your vivid description of slipping on ice. This anchors the reader in the moment before revealing your decision to join track.  
• Group the rehabilitation details into one paragraph:  
  – Combine “Later, in physical therapy…” with a few extra descriptive sentences about your exercises or feelings. This makes the therapy phase feel more cohesive.  
• Conclude with a reflective summary:  
  – After “Joining track taught me…,” add a brief reflection sentence that ties back to hope or future goals. This bookends your narrative with the reflective, hopeful tone you want.  

Opportunities for Improvement  
• Add sensory details: Describe the sharp sting of cold air in your lungs as you fell or the squeak of sneakers on the track.  
• Vary sentence length: Mix one- or two-word exclamations (“Ouch!”) or questions (“Could I do this?”) with longer, flowing sentences for emphasis.  
• Strengthen transitions: Use words like “after,” “soon,” or “as a result” to show cause and effect between injury, therapy, and joining track.  

Formatting Guidance  
• Paragraphs:  
  – Paragraph 1: The fall and decision to join track.  
  – Paragraph 2: Physical therapy experience.  
  – Paragraph 3: Returning to running and lesson learned.  
• Standard essay style:  
  – Double-space your text, use 12-point Times New Roman, and indent the first line of each paragraph.  
  – No subheadings—let the flow of your narrative guide the reader.  

Would you like me to generate a fully rewritten version of your narrative that incorporates these edits? Let me know if you’d like further assistance, more examples, or any additional changes!",

text: Subject: Extension for Research Brief Due Sept 28
Hi Professor Ahmed,

    "coverageText": "Overview  
Based on your goals—making the email polite and clear, fixing grammar and formatting, and suggesting a strong professional structure—I’ve focused on clarity, formality, and concise phrasing appropriate for a college-level email to a professor. Key areas include hyphenation, date and time formatting, paragraph division, and a more specific subject line.

Overall Feedback  
Your draft is concise and respectful, which fits your tone preference. To increase clarity and formality, I recommend:
• Hyphenating compound modifiers and spelling out months in full.  
• Splitting the body into two short paragraphs (context then request) for better flow.  
• Adding a brief opening line (e.g., “I hope you are well”) to soften the request.  
• Refining the subject line to state the exact request (“48-Hour Extension”).  

Spelling Edits  
• None detected – all words are spelled correctly.

Grammar Edits  
• Original: “I am requesting a 48 hour extension for the research brief due Sept 28.”  
  Correction: “I am requesting a 48-hour extension for the research brief due September 28.”  
  Reasoning: Hyphenate the compound adjective “48-hour” (grammar) and spell out the month for formality (style).

• Original: “If approved, I will submit by Sept 30 at 11:59pm.”  
  Correction: “If approved, I will submit it by September 30 at 11:59 p.m.”  
  Reasoning: Add the pronoun “it” for clarity (grammar), spell out the month (style), and format time with periods and a space before “p.m.” (style/consistency).

Structural Suggestions  
• Add a brief opener: Insert “I hope you are well.” before stating your request. This enhances tone and rapport.  
• Divide the body into two paragraphs:  
  – Paragraph 1: Context (“I have completed most of the reading, but I need extra time…”)  
  – Paragraph 2: Request and deadline (“Would you please grant me…” + specify new date/time).  
  This separation improves readability and highlights the request.  
• Refine the subject line: Change it to “Request for 48-Hour Extension on Research Brief Due September 28.” A precise subject helps your professor immediately know what you need.

Opportunities for Improvement  
• Consider adding a one-sentence expression of gratitude in advance (“I appreciate your understanding and support.”) to strengthen politeness.  
• Use “would you please” instead of “I am requesting” to soften the tone.  
• Confirm receipt: you might add, “Please let me know if this is acceptable.” to invite a reply.

Formatting Guidance  
• Subject Line: Make it action-oriented and specific (see Structural Suggestions).  
• Greeting: “Dear Professor Ahmed,” is slightly more formal than “Hi Professor Ahmed,” but either is acceptable.  
• Opening Line: A brief pleasantry (“I hope you’re doing well.”).  
• Paragraphing: Two short paragraphs as outlined above.  
• Closing: Use “Thank you for your time and consideration.”  
• Sign-off: “Sincerely,” or “Best regards,” followed by your full name on the next line.  
• Spacing: Single-space within paragraphs, double-space between paragraphs and around signature.

Would you like me to generate a fully revised version of your email with these changes? Or is there any other aspect you’d like to adjust?",

Based on your goal to eliminate comma splices and run-ons, strengthen your thesis and paragraph structure, and follow basic MLA formatting for a compare-and-contrast essay, this edit will:

- Tackle line-by-line grammar fixes (especially comma splices/run-ons)  
- Suggest a clearer, stronger thesis statement  
- Offer block-versus-point-by-point organization ideas  
- Ensure MLA basics (font, spacing, header)  

Overall Feedback  
Your excerpt introduces a solid comparison between ebooks and print books, but the thesis is implicit and the sentences run together. I recommend making the thesis explicit in the introduction, breaking the content into at least two paragraphs (one on convenience vs comfort, one on annotation habits), and adding clear transitions. This will create a sharper argument for your high-school English teacher audience and make each point stand out.

Spelling Edits  
(No misspellings detected in the provided text.)

Grammar Edits  
- “While ebooks are convenient because you can carry many in one device, print books have advantages too, they are easier on the eyes and don’t need batteries.”  
  • Issue: Comma splice/run-on  
  • Fix: Separate into two independent clauses or use a semicolon.  
  • Suggested rewrite: “While ebooks are convenient—you can carry many titles on one device—print books have advantages too. They are easier on the eyes and don’t need batteries.”  

- “Also I think annotations feel different, on a screen I highlight too much and it loses meaning, with paper I slow down more.”  
  • Issue: Missing comma after introductory “Also” and two comma splices.  
  • Fix: Add comma after “Also” and break into two sentences or use semicolons.  
  • Suggested rewrite: “Also, I think annotations feel different. On a screen, I highlight too much and it loses meaning; with paper, I slow down more.”  

- “Both formats can be good but it depends on the reader and the situation.”  
  • Issue: Missing comma before coordinating conjunction “but.”  
  • Fix: Insert comma for clarity.  
  • Suggested rewrite: “Both formats can be good, but it depends on the reader and the situation.”  

Structural Suggestions  
- Introduce a clear thesis in a standalone opening paragraph.  
  • Benefit: Signals to the reader exactly what you will compare and contrast.  
- Divide the excerpt into two body paragraphs:  
  1. Convenience vs. comfort (device portability, eye strain, battery life)  
  2. Annotation habits (digital highlighting vs. paper‐based note-taking)  
  • Benefit: Organizes points either by block (all ebook points then all print points) or by point-by-point (address portability for both, then annotation for both).  
- End with a brief conclusion paragraph that restates the thesis and reflects on when each format is best.  
  • Benefit: Gives closure and leaves the reader with a clear takeaway.  

Opportunities for Improvement  
- Make the thesis more analytical by stating why the comparison matters (for example, “Understanding these differences helps readers choose the best format for study or leisure.”).  
- Add brief examples or scenarios (e.g., “For students pulling an all-nighter, digital search functions can save time…”).  
- Use transitional words (however, conversely, similarly) to highlight contrasts and similarities.  

Formatting Guidance  
- Use 12-point Times New Roman, double-spaced, with 1-inch margins.  
- Include an MLA header on the first page (your name, instructor name, course, date).  
- Center your essay title between the header and your text.  
- Indent each new paragraph ½ inch.  
- Use parenthetical citations only if you quote or paraphrase sources (not needed here).

Based on your goals (improving clarity and specificity, fixing articles and verb forms, and suggesting a stronger conclusion) and your audience (class blog readers), I’ve focused on tightening your analysis, correcting small grammatical issues, and reshaping your ending so it makes a stronger thematic point—all while preserving the chosen opening storm scene and avoiding spoilers beyond the first 30 minutes.

Overall Feedback  
Your paragraph effectively highlights how the storm scene establishes tension and foreshadows the film’s survival theme. To sharpen it for a blog audience, I recommend:  
- Naming or specifying “the commander” for clarity  
- Maintaining present-tense consistency throughout  
- Varying sentence structure to improve flow  
- Ending with a stronger concluding sentence that ties back to your main point  

Spelling Edits  
• No spelling errors detected. Your word choice is clear, and all terms are spelled correctly.

Grammar Edits  
• “Commander makes fast call” → “The commander makes a quick decision.”  
  ­­Issue: article usage and style. Explanation: Adding “The” clarifies who you mean, and “quick decision” reads more naturally than “fast call.”  
• “it put us in chaos” → “it puts the audience in chaos.”  
  Issue: verb tense consistency and pronoun clarity. Explanation: “Puts” keeps present tense, and “the audience” is more formal than “us.”  
• “The sound mix is loud and harsh, it put us in chaos.” → two sentences or semicolon:  
   “The sound mix is loud and harsh; it puts the audience in chaos.”  
  Issue: comma splice. Explanation: A semicolon or period correctly separates two independent clauses.  
• “group decision under pressure” → “group decision-making under pressure”  
  Issue: style and clarity. Explanation: The hyphenated phrase “decision-making” more precisely names the process.

Structural Suggestions  
• Combine context and analysis for smoother flow. For example, merge your first two sentences:  
  Original: “In the opening of *The Martian*, the storm scene shows how group decision under pressure can go wrong. Commander makes fast call and it seems rational…”  
  Suggested: “In the opening of *The Martian*, a dust storm forces the crew’s commander to order an emergency evacuation—an ostensibly rational call that, through tight framing on worried faces, reveals the flaws of group decision-making under pressure.”  
  How it helps: Condenses setup and analysis into one dynamic sentence, making your writing more concise.  
• Expand briefly on the camera work. You mention “the camera shows doubt on faces”; consider noting specific shots (e.g., close-ups, shaky handheld) to strengthen your evidence.  
• Place your thematic insight at the end, but add a more definitive conclusion:  
  “This early sequence not only immerses viewers in chaos but also foreshadows the core struggle of *The Martian*: balancing split-second judgments with meticulous planning for survival.”  
  How it helps: Provides a clear, thematic wrap-up that reinforces why the scene matters.

Opportunities for Improvement  
• Identify the commander by name (Commander Lewis) to ground readers in characters.  
• Describe camera techniques (e.g., quick cuts, tight close-ups) to support your claim about tension.  
• Add a brief transition (“Moreover,” “In doing so,” etc.) when you move from the sound mix to thematic setup for better flow.  
• Consider a one-sentence tie-back to how this scene connects to Mark Watney’s later challenges, without spoiling plot points.

Formatting Guidance  
• Italicize film titles: *The Martian*.  
• Keep analysis in present tense—standard for film critique.  
• Break into two short paragraphs: one describing the scene and one drawing out the thematic significance.  
• On a web post, use headings or subheads if you expand the section (e.g., “Setting the Stage,” “Foreshadowing Survival”).

Would you like me to generate a revised version of your paragraph incorporating these suggestions? Or do you need more feedback or assistance on any specific point?",

text: Ms. Johnson, a veteran and math teacher, started the after-school coding club to help students who felt left out of tech. “Everybody can learn to code,” she said, “we just need a place to try and fail safely.” The club has students from different backgrounds and abilities and they pair up to solve small problems. This directly matches the specification’s allowance for prose plus accompanying instructions on goals, audience, and formatting. There are no attachments, prohibited content, or unsupported elements.  
OK",

    "coverageText": "Overview  
This edit focuses on tightening punctuation and capitalization, clarifying and condensing phrasing, and applying AP style for a community profile article in a school newspaper. We’ll preserve Ms. Johnson’s quotes verbatim, respect the portrayal of all students, and suggest structural tweaks and formatting tips for smooth reading and clear attribution.

Overall Feedback  
• The profile provides a warm, inclusive snapshot of the coding club, but a few sentences run together or use comma splices. Breaking them into shorter, clearer statements will improve flow.  
• Applying AP style will standardize titles, numbers, and quotation formatting.  
• Adding brief context—such as the school’s name or the club’s size—and paragraph breaks will give readers landmarks and make the article more engaging.

Spelling Edits  
• No misspellings were found in the submitted text.

Grammar Edits  
• “Ms. Johnson, a veteran and math teacher, started the after-school coding club to help students who felt left out of tech.”  
  – Issue: “math teacher” (style)  
  – Correction: “mathematics teacher”  
  – Reason: AP style prefers “mathematics” in formal titles (style).

• “…‘Everybody can learn to code,’ she said, ‘we just need a place to try and fail safely.’”  
  – Issue: run-on quotation and lowercase after comma (punctuation, grammar)  
  – Correction: “‘Everybody can learn to code,’ she said. ‘We just need a place to try and fail safely.’”  
  – Reason: Separate into two sentences for clarity; capitalize “We” per standard sentence rules (AP style).

• “The club has students from different backgrounds and abilities and they pair up to solve small problems.”  
  – Issue: missing comma or conjunction (grammar)  
  – Correction: “The club has students from different backgrounds and abilities, and they pair up to solve small problems.”  
  – Reason: Add comma before “and” linking two independent clauses (comma use).

• “Last week they built an app that shows bus schedules, it was buggy but then they fixed it together.”  
  – Issue: comma splice (grammar)  
  – Correction: “Last week, they built an app that shows bus schedules. It was buggy, but they fixed it together.”  
  – Reason: Split into two sentences to avoid comma splice; add comma before “but” in a compound sentence.

Structural Suggestions  
1. Lead with context: Begin with the school name and number of club members.  
   – Example: “At Lincoln High School, 15 students come together every Wednesday after class…”  
   – Improves reader orientation and stakes.  
2. Break into paragraphs:  
   – Paragraph 1: Introduction of Ms. Johnson and club purpose.  
   – Paragraph 2: Include her quote about coding.  
   – Paragraph 3: Describe student collaboration and recent project.  
   – Paragraph 4: Concluding atmosphere and future plans.  
   – Adds visual breaks and logical flow.  
3. Close with impact: Add a final quote or statistic about student success or upcoming showcase.  
   – Strengthens conclusion and leaves readers with a clear takeaway.

Opportunities for Improvement  
• Add specific student voices or a short quote (with permission) to illustrate “different backgrounds.”  
• Provide concrete examples of problem-solving challenges to deepen reader engagement.  
• Use transition words (“For example,” “As a result,” “Next”) for smoother connections between ideas.  
• Mention the club’s meeting time or location for practical value to readers.

Formatting Guidance  
• AP style for titles: Use “Ms. Johnson” on first reference without academic degrees; thereafter use “Johnson.”  
• Numbers: Spell out numbers under 10 (e.g., “five students”), use numerals for 10 and above.  
• Quotes: Double quotes for all speech; separate distinct sentences into their own quoted blocks with proper attribution.  
• Paragraphing: Keep each main idea in its own paragraph.  
• Dates/times: Write as “4 p.m. Tuesdays” (lowercase abbreviations, periods in a.m./p.m.).

text: Growing up as a first-generation Mexican American, I often translated bank forms for my parents and tried to make sense of bills with unfamiliar words. At first, I felt small in those offices, like I was pretending to be older. Over time, I realized I was learning a language of responsibility. When my mom’s small catering business almost closed during the pandemic, I made flyers, wrote emails, and built a simple website on my cracked phone. It wasn’t perfect, but it worked, and we kept going. This taught me how community isn’t a slogan; it’s people showing up for each other. I still worry about sounding “right,” but I’ve learned to ask questions and keep trying even when I’m unsure. College, to me, is a place to grow that force of trying into something that can help others, especially families navigating systems that pretend to be simple.

text: Title: How I Stopped Procrastinating By Doing Less
Intro: I used to think I need more apps to fix my procrastination. Turns out, I needed less—less options, less tabs, less guilt.
## Tip 1: Make a Not-To-Do List
This is not negative! It focuses your attention on what you should ignore. For example, checking Twitter every 10 minutes is a bad loop I had.
## Tip 2: Set "good enough" deadlines
Perfectionism is a trap. If you schedule shorter blocks and accept B+ work at first, you will move faster.
## Conclusion
Doing less is surprisingly brave. You will feel weird at first, but then free.

promptPexTests.user_input: greeting: Hi! type: essay audience: general public goal: (not provided) feedback: (not provided) text: I wrote a short paragraph about climate change. Weather is effecting farmers alot. The data are scattered and I was going to add more later. It's kind of messy, and I don't know if its good.
promptPexTests.testinput: greeting: Hi! type: essay audience: general public goal: (not provided) feedback: (not provided) text: I wrote a short paragraph about climate change. Weather is effecting farmers alot. The data are scattered and I was going to add more later. It's kind of messy, and I don't know if its good.
promptPexTests.groundtruth:
Hi! I’m here to help you edit and improve your writing. I can give line-by-line edits on spelling, grammar, phrasing, and structure, and I can also suggest how to organize your ideas for your audience.

A few quick questions to understand your goals:
- How long do you want the paragraph to be (one short paragraph or a few)?
- Do you want it to be informative, persuasive, or both?
- Should it focus on farmers in a specific region, or be general?
- Do you plan to include data/statistics, or keep it high-level?

Overview of the approach:
- I’ll clean up grammar and spelling, tighten phrasing, and make the weather–climate connection clear.
- I’ll suggest a simple structure: a clear topic sentence, 1–2 supporting points (examples or data), and a concise concluding idea.
- I’ll offer a polished version you can use or adapt.

Overall Feedback:
- You’re flagging a timely topic and a clear audience. To make this effective for the general public, avoid meta statements (like “I was going to add more later”) in the final paragraph, and connect weather impacts directly to climate change so the cause-and-effect relationship is clear.
- Aim for specific examples (droughts, floods, unpredictable seasons) and simple, direct language.
- Keep tense consistent and avoid filler phrases (“kind of,” “a lot”) unless they add meaning.

Spelling Edits (with explanations):
- “effecting” → “affecting”
  - “Affecting” means “influencing or having an impact on.” “Effecting” means “causing to happen,” which isn’t the intended meaning here.
- “alot” → “a lot”
  - “A lot” is two words in standard English.
- “its good” → “it’s good”
  - Use “it’s” (it is). “Its” is possessive.

Grammar and Phrasing Edits (with explanations):
- Original: “Weather is effecting farmers alot.”
  - Suggested: “Extreme weather is affecting farmers a lot.”
  - Why: Correct spelling and verb; add “Extreme” to be more precise. Consider replacing “a lot” with “significantly” or describing how (e.g., “by reducing yields and raising costs”) for specificity.
- Original: “The data are scattered and I was going to add more later.”
  - Suggested (general public style): “The available data are scattered, and I plan to add more later.”
  - Why: “Plan” keeps tense consistent; “available” clarifies what’s scattered. For a finished essay, remove meta-process notes entirely and present one or two specific data points instead.
- Original: “It’s kind of messy, and I don’t know if its good.”
  - Suggested: “It’s a bit messy, and I’m not sure it reads well.”
  - Why: Replace filler (“kind of”) with “a bit,” correct “it’s,” and be specific about what “good” means (clarity/readability). For the final essay, avoid self-assessment and simply present a clean paragraph.

Structural Suggestions:
- Use a clear 3–4 sentence structure:
  1) Topic sentence: connect climate change to weather and farmers.
  2) Supporting detail: examples of impacts (droughts, floods, unpredictable seasons).
  3) Optional evidence: one clear statistic or observed trend (cite a credible source if you have one).
  4) Closing sentence: why it matters or what should happen next (adaptation/support/emissions reductions).
- Remove meta commentary (“I was going to add more later”) from the final paragraph. Keep that note in your draft, not in the published text.

Opportunities for Improvement:
- Replace vague phrases (“a lot,” “kind of messy”) with concrete examples.
- Clarify the weather–climate link (e.g., “Climate change is intensifying extreme weather…”).
- If you include data, choose one or two key numbers with plain-language context and a source.
- Use active voice and short sentences to increase readability.

Formatting Guidance:
- For a short general-public essay, stick to one concise paragraph (3–5 sentences).
- Use plain language, avoid jargon, and define terms briefly if needed (e.g., “extreme weather”).
- If you expand to multiple paragraphs, add a short subheading and break up ideas for readability.

Would you like me to rewrite this into a clean, ready-to-share paragraph now? If so, tell me your preferred tone (informative vs. persuasive) and any region or example you want included. Here’s a neutral, general-public example you could use or tweak:

Example revised paragraph:
Climate change is intensifying extreme weather, and farmers are feeling the effects. Droughts, floods, and unpredictable seasons reduce yields and raise costs, making harvests less reliable and food prices more volatile. Clear, consistent data help us understand these trends, but the takeaway is already clear: we need to support farmers’ adaptation efforts while reducing emissions to limit future damage.

If you share your target length and any data you want included, I can tailor this further and provide a fully edited version.

promptPexTests.expectedoutput: Contains a distinct section labeled 'Overview' that briefly summarizes the editorial approach and focus areas based on the provided goals and type (argumentative essay).
promptPexTests.reasoning: None; input adheres to specification; includes stated goals, type, and target audience for alignment.
promptPexTests.user_input: goal: strengthen thesis clarity and persuasive impact type: argumentative essay audience: high school teacher feedback: line-by-line edits and overview text: School uniforms should be adopted because they reduce bullying. However my thesis is vague and I don't consistently support claims. I want stronger transitions and a clearer stance.
promptPexTests.testinput: goal: strengthen thesis clarity and persuasive impact type: argumentative essay audience: high school teacher feedback: line-by-line edits and overview text: School uniforms should be adopted because they reduce bullying. However my thesis is vague and I don't consistently support claims. I want stronger transitions and a clearer stance.
promptPexTests.groundtruth:
Thanks for sharing your goals. I’m here to help strengthen your thesis clarity and persuasive impact for an argumentative essay. I’ll give line-by-line edits with reasoning, then broader guidance on structure, transitions, and stance.

Quick questions to tailor the edit:
- Do you need to include evidence or citations (studies, school policy examples)?
- Are you required to address counterarguments (e.g., cost, student expression)?
- What length is the essay (word count or number of paragraphs)?
- Any specific formatting (MLA, APA) or rubric requirements from your teacher?

Overview of how I’ll help:
- Clarify and sharpen your thesis so it gives a strong, specific stance and previews your main reasons.
- Replace meta-commentary with purposeful sentences suitable for your essay introduction.
- Suggest effective transitions and a logical structure for your body paragraphs and conclusion.
- Offer multiple thesis options and a sample introduction paragraph you can use or adapt.

Line-by-line edits with reasoning:
1) Original: “School uniforms should be adopted because they reduce bullying.”
   Suggested edit: “Schools should require uniforms because standardizing dress reduces status competition and appearance-based bullying.”
   Why: “Should require” is more direct and active than “should be adopted.” Adding “standardizing dress” and “appearance-based bullying” clarifies the mechanism and narrows the claim for precision.

2) Original: “However my thesis is vague and I don't consistently support claims.”
   Suggested edit: Remove from the essay.
   Why: This is self-referential meta-commentary, not content your audience needs. If you want a planning sentence, you can instead write: “This essay explains how uniforms curb bullying and supports the claim with evidence from schools and research.” But typically, just use a clear thesis and let the body paragraphs provide support.

3) Original: “I want stronger transitions and a clearer stance.”
   Suggested edit: Remove from the essay.
   Why: Also meta-commentary. Replace with an actual clear stance (the revised thesis) and use transitions within and between body paragraphs.

Overall Feedback:
- Your core claim is solid, but it needs a stronger, more specific thesis that states how uniforms reduce bullying (the mechanism) and previews the points you’ll argue.
- Remove self-referential sentences from the draft; replace them with argumentative content.
- Use consistent, active voice and topic sentences that directly support the thesis.
- Integrate transitions that show logical progression: begin with mechanism, move to evidence, then address counterarguments before concluding.

Spelling Edits:
- No spelling errors in your text.

Grammar Edits:
- Add a comma after introductory “However” if you keep that sentence in any future draft: “However, …”
- Prefer active voice (“schools should require”) over passive (“should be adopted”) for a stronger, more persuasive tone.
- Avoid first-person meta-statements in an argumentative essay unless your assignment encourages reflection.

Structural Suggestions:
- Introduction: Hook, brief context, precise thesis.
- Body paragraph 1 (Mechanism): Explain how uniforms reduce visible status markers and remove appearance-based targets for bullying.
- Body paragraph 2 (Evidence): Present examples or data from school districts or studies showing reduced bullying incidents after uniform adoption.
- Body paragraph 3 (Counterargument and rebuttal): Acknowledge concerns (cost, individuality) and rebut with solutions (assistance programs, optional accessories, focus on safety).
- Conclusion: Restate thesis in fresh words, synthesize key points, and end with a call to action or implication (e.g., schools should pilot uniform policies with equity supports).

Opportunities for Improvement:
- Define bullying briefly (appearance-based teasing, brand shaming) to focus your claim.
- Specify the scope (e.g., public middle and high schools) to avoid overgeneralization.
- Support claims with credible sources (district reports, education research) or real-world examples; avoid overclaiming causation without evidence.
- Use clear topic sentences that tie directly back to the thesis at the start of each body paragraph.
- Maintain parallel structure when listing reasons: “reduces status competition, removes appearance-based targets, and fosters a sense of belonging.”

Formatting Guidance:
- Use a standard argumentative format: double-spaced, readable font, clear paragraph breaks, and consistent heading style if required by your teacher.
- If citing sources, include in-text citations and a works cited page (MLA is common for high school).
- Keep paragraphs focused: one main idea per paragraph with a strong topic sentence and concluding link back to the thesis.

Stronger thesis options (choose one or adapt):
- “Public schools should require uniforms because standardizing dress reduces status competition, removes appearance-based targets for bullying, and builds a culture of belonging.”
- “To make campuses safer, schools should require uniforms; by removing visible status markers, uniforms cut the fuel for bullying and refocus attention on learning.”
- “Schools should adopt uniforms to reduce bullying: when clothing is standardized, students have fewer reasons to judge, isolate, or harass peers over appearance or brand.”

Sample introduction paragraph (ready to use or adapt):
- “No student should dread walking into school because of what they wear. Bullying often targets appearance—brands, styles, and price tags become excuses to judge and exclude. Schools should require uniforms because standardizing dress reduces status competition and appearance-based bullying. By removing visible markers that separate students into ‘haves’ and ‘have-nots,’ uniforms help create a more respectful environment where attention can return to learning.”

Sample topic sentences and transitions:
- Body 1: “First, uniforms reduce status competition by eliminating the brand and style differences that often trigger teasing.”
- Body 2: “Moreover, schools that adopt uniform policies report fewer appearance-based conflicts, suggesting uniforms help curb bullying.”
- Body 3 (counterargument): “Critics argue that uniforms limit self-expression and can be costly; however, schools can allow personal accessories and provide assistance programs, maintaining safety without sacrificing equity.”
- Conclusion: “Ultimately, by removing appearance-based targets and promoting belonging, uniforms are a practical step schools can take to reduce bullying.”

Would you like me to rewrite your thesis, introduction, and an outline for the full essay based on your assignment length and requirements? If you share any rubric details or source expectations, I can tailor the draft and provide transitions throughout.

promptPexTests.expectedoutput: The output is structured into the exact headings: Overall Feedback, Spelling Edits, Grammar Edits, Structural Suggestions, Opportunities for Improvement, Formatting Guidance.
promptPexTests.reasoning: None; input complies; realistic business letter scenario requiring full structured response.
promptPexTests.user_input: goal: refine tone for professional readers type: business letter audience: potential clients feedback: comprehensive edits text: Dear Sir or Madam, I hope this email finds you well. We offer services that is tailored to your needs, and we want to ensure your satisfaction, we will be happy to help. Please let me know if you have any question.
promptPexTests.testinput: goal: refine tone for professional readers type: business letter audience: potential clients feedback: comprehensive edits text: Dear Sir or Madam, I hope this email finds you well. We offer services that is tailored to your needs, and we want to ensure your satisfaction, we will be happy to help. Please let me know if you have any question.
promptPexTests.groundtruth:
Thanks for sharing your goals and the draft. I can help refine the tone for professional readers and give comprehensive, line-by-line edits.

A couple of quick questions to tailor the rewrite:
- What is the name of your company and the main services you offer (e.g., consulting, design, software development)?
- Do you prefer a formal business letter or a concise business email? Your draft mentions “email,” but your goal says “business letter.
- What action do you want the recipient to take (schedule a call, request a proposal, reply with questions)?
- Do you have a specific recipient name or title to address?

Overview of editorial guidance I’ll provide
- Modernize the salutation and make it more personal and professional.
- Fix grammar and punctuation issues (subject–verb agreement, comma splices, plural nouns).
- Align pronouns and tone (consistent “we” vs. “I”).
- Strengthen clarity and add a specific call to action.
- Tailor wording for either a formal letter or a concise email format.

Categorized feedback

Overall Feedback
- The tone is polite but generic. Professional readers prefer clear value statements and a specific next step.
- Replace outdated or impersonal salutations (“Dear Sir or Madam”) with a name or role-based greeting.
- Remove or shorten cliché openers (“I hope this email finds you well”) to keep the message concise and professional.
- Make the call to action specific (e.g., propose a time for a call or invite them to request a proposal).

Spelling Edits
- “Please let me know if you have any question.” → “Please let me know if you have any questions.”
  Reason: “Questions” should be plural when referring to any number of potential questions.

Grammar Edits
- “We offer services that is tailored to your needs” → “We offer services that are tailored to your needs”
  Reason: Subject–verb agreement. “Services” is plural, so use “are.”
- “...and we want to ensure your satisfaction, we will be happy to help.” → Split into two sentences or use a coordinating conjunction.
  Reason: Comma splice. Two independent clauses joined by a comma should be separated by a period, semicolon, or conjunction.
- Pronoun consistency: You switch from “we” to “me” in the last sentence.
  Suggestion: Use “we” throughout if writing on behalf of the company, or “I” if writing as a representative.

Structural Suggestions
- Use a clear, direct opener that states your value: what you do and why it matters to the client.
- Follow with a brief assurance or benefit (commitment to satisfaction).
- End with a specific call to action (propose a meeting, invite a reply, provide contact details).
- If this is a letter, include a professional sign-off and full contact details. If it’s an email, add a relevant subject line and keep paragraphs short.

Opportunities for Improvement
- Add one sentence describing the specific services or outcomes (e.g., “We help [type of client] achieve [result] through [service].”).
- Include a brief credibility element (e.g., years in business, notable clients, or a quick metric).
- Offer a concrete next step with a suggested time (e.g., “Could we schedule a 15-minute call next week?”).
- Personalize the greeting with the recipient’s name or role.

Formatting Guidance
- Business letter:
  - Your Name, Title, Company, Address, Phone, Email
  - Date
  - Recipient Name, Title, Company, Address
  - Salutation
  - 2–3 short paragraphs (value, benefit, CTA)
  - Professional closing (Sincerely/Best regards) + signature block
- Business email:
  - Subject line (clear benefit, concise)
  - Greeting with name
  - 2 short paragraphs (value + CTA)
  - Signature with full contact info

Line-by-line edits with reasoning

Original: “Dear Sir or Madam,”
- Edit: “Dear [Recipient’s Name],” or “Dear [Title/Team],”
- Reason: “Dear Sir or Madam” is dated and impersonal. Using a name or role feels more professional and client-focused.

Original: “I hope this email finds you well.”
- Edit options:
  - Remove entirely for concision.
  - Or: “I hope you’re well.”
- Reason: This phrase is common but can feel generic. Many professional readers prefer getting to the point.

Original: “We offer services that is tailored to your needs, and we want to ensure your satisfaction, we will be happy to help.”
- Edit: “Our services are tailored to your needs, and we are committed to your satisfaction. We would be happy to discuss how we can support your goals.”
- Reason: Fix subject–verb agreement; eliminate comma splice; strengthen tone by clarifying benefits and using parallel structure.

Original: “Please let me know if you have any question.”
- Edit: “Please let us know a convenient time to talk, or reply with any questions.”
- Reason: Pluralize “questions,” make the CTA specific, and keep pronouns consistent.

Would you like me to generate the edited text?
Below are two polished versions you can use immediately. I’ll tailor them further once you confirm whether this is a letter or email and share your service details.

Option A – Formal business letter
Dear [Recipient Name],

Our services are tailored to your needs, and we are committed to your satisfaction. We would welcome the opportunity to discuss how we can support your goals.

Please let us know a convenient time to connect, or contact me directly at [phone] or [email]. I look forward to speaking with you.

Sincerely,
[Your Name]
[Title]
[Company]
[Phone] | [Email] | [Website]

Option B – Concise business email
Subject: Tailored services to support [Client Company]’s goals

Dear [Recipient Name],

We provide services tailored to your needs and are committed to your satisfaction. I’d be happy to share a brief overview and explore how we can help.

Could we schedule a 15-minute call next week? Please reply with a time that works for you, or reach me at [phone/email].

Best regards,
[Your Name]
[Title], [Company]
[Phone] | [Email] | [Website]

Would you like me to incorporate your company name, services, and a specific CTA into one final version? I can also adjust the tone to be more formal or more conversational, depending on your preference.

promptPexTests.expectedoutput: The 'Overall Feedback' section summarizes main feedback themes and provides general guidance explicitly aligned with the user's goals and intended audience.
promptPexTests.reasoning: None; input complies; includes explicit goals and audience for alignment testing.
promptPexTests.user_input: goal: convey authenticity while staying concise type: personal statement audience: college admissions committee feedback: detailed critique text: Growing up in a small town taught me resilience and curiosity. I want to show my passion for biology without sounding arrogant. I'm not sure if my anecdotes connect to my central message or if the tone fits my audience.
promptPexTests.testinput: goal: convey authenticity while staying concise type: personal statement audience: college admissions committee feedback: detailed critique text: Growing up in a small town taught me resilience and curiosity. I want to show my passion for biology without sounding arrogant. I'm not sure if my anecdotes connect to my central message or if the tone fits my audience.
promptPexTests.groundtruth:
Thanks for sharing your goals and audience. I help edit writing line by line and give clear, constructive feedback on tone, clarity, grammar, structure, and formatting. Before we dive in, two quick questions to tailor the feedback:
- What is your central message in one sentence (for example: “Curiosity drives me to explore biology through hands-on problem solving”)?
- Which specific anecdotes are you considering (e.g., a lab project, fieldwork, a challenge you overcame)? And what word count are you targeting?

Overview of the approach
- I’ll give precise line-by-line edits of the text you shared, with reasoning.
- I’ll then provide categorized feedback on tone, concision, authenticity, and structure tailored to a college admissions audience.
- I’ll suggest how to link anecdotes to your central message and keep the tone confident yet humble.
- If you want, I can draft a revised opening or the full personal statement after we discuss your anecdotes.

Line-by-line edits with reasoning
1) Original: “Growing up in a small town taught me resilience and curiosity.”
   - Edited: “Growing up in a small town shaped my resilience and curiosity.”
   - Reasoning: “Shaped” is more concise and feels less cliché than “taught me,” while still showing growth. Consider replacing abstract traits (“resilience,” “curiosity”) with a concrete detail later (e.g., a specific moment or habit) to convey authenticity.

2) Original: “I want to show my passion for biology without sounding arrogant.”
   - Edited: “I aim to convey my passion for biology with humility.”
   - Reasoning: Positive framing (“convey … with humility”) is concise and avoids the meta “show” language. In the essay itself, don’t state this intent—demonstrate it through choices, actions, and reflective insight.

3) Original: “I’m not sure if my anecdotes connect to my central message or if the tone fits my audience.”
   - Edited: “I’m working to ensure my anecdotes reinforce a clear central message and suit a college admissions audience.”
   - Reasoning: More assertive and concise (“working to ensure” + “reinforce a clear central message”). In the essay, replace uncertainty with clear transitions and reflective sentences that explicitly tie each anecdote to your message.

Overall Feedback
- Authenticity: Avoid general claims (“resilience,” “curiosity”) unless you ground them in vivid, specific moments. Specifics make you memorable and humble.
- Concision: Replace meta statements (what you want to show) with actions and reflection. Trim filler (“I want to,” “I’m not sure if”) and use strong verbs.
- Tone for admissions: Confident, reflective, and collaborative. Show impact on others or learning from setbacks. Avoid grandiose language and excessive self-praise.
- Connection: After each anecdote, include a 1–2 sentence reflection that ties it back to your central message and forward to your future goals in biology.

Spelling Edits
- No spelling errors in the lines you shared.
